Graphical abstract Highlights ► Using an in situ method to synthesize the sandwich lamination structure of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. ► Pt nanoparticles were fabricated on Gr-CNTs via a simple one-step chemical reduction method. ► The Pt/Gr-CNTs have high electro-catalytic activity for methanol oxidation in neutral medium. The sandwich lamination structure of graphene-multi-walled carbon nanotubes (Gr-CNTs) nanocomposite has been fabricated through in situ facile and green method. Then Pt nanoparticles are fabricated on Gr-CNTs via a simple one-step chemical reduction method in ethylene glycol (EG) and water system. The Gr-CNTs nanocomposite increased the solubility of carbon nanotubes in water, and CNTs could effectively prevent the irreversible aggregation of graphene. The Pt/Gr-CNTs were further characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), which indicated that the as-synthesized Pt nanoparticles were successfully dispersed on the surface of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. Electrochemical study has proved that the Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite has higher catalytic activity in neutral medium for methanol oxidation, which is hopefully used in various types of cells and biosensors in physiological medium. Keywords Graphene Graphene-carbon nanotubes Methanol Platinum Electro-oxidation 1 Introduction Carbon nanotubes and nanostructures have drawn attention because of their unusual electronic properties and ability to improve catalytic properties [1,2]. However, carbon nanotubes are so difficult to be dissolved in water which limits its application in a wide range. More researches have paid attention to do functional and modification works to improve aqueous solubility of carbon nanotubes [3]. In addition, graphene (Gr) is a counterpart of graphite with well separated 2-D aromatic sheets composed of sp2-bonded carbon atoms which can greatly improve electronic and thermal conductivities [4]. Consequently, the unique electronic property of Gr nanosheets provides potential applications in synthesizing nano-materials and fabricating various micro-electrical devices [5]. However, single Gr nanosheets are unstable and easily aggregate into graphite. So challenges remaining for achieving good and stable dispersion of Gr sheets pose significant obstacles to these goals. Several effective techniques have been developed for preparing a good dispersion of Gr sheets [6–8]. Recently, the combination of 2-D Gr sheets and CNTs to design hierarchically structured composites has been extensively studied in lithium ion batteries [9], supercapacitors [10,11] and transparent conductors [12–15]. Great improvements in performance have been observed in these materials as CNTs can bridge the defects for electron transfer and expand the layer distance between Gr sheets. Therefore, the inclusion of CNTs is expected to improve the unique potential of Gr films as a free-standing electrode for supercapacitors [16–18] and sensors. But there are few literatures on the preparation and application of Gr-CNTs in various types of cells and sensors. The purpose of this study is to use a facile and green method in situ to synthesize the sandwich lamination structure of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite, and use the material as a catalyst carrier to load Pt nanoparticles for electrochemical sensing. In this work, we demonstrated the preparation of a Pt/Gr/CNTs nanocomposite by ethylene glycol (EG) reduction of GO/CNTs, and GO/CNT films were obtained by filtration of the complex dispersion of GO and CNTs. The Gr-CNTs nanocomposite can be easily prepared in the solution phase mixed the graphene sheets with CNTs. When the course was finished, the new nanocomposite increased the solubility of carbon nanotubes in water. Simultaneously, the carbon nanotubes could effectively prevent the irreversible aggregation of graphene. The new nanocomposite was proposed to be a good carrier of precious metal catalyst. Furthermore, the electrocatalytic activity to methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs was studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and chronoamperometry. There are many literatures about Pt/Gr and Pt/CNTs that describe their electrocatalytic activities for methanol oxidation [19–32]. In this work, the oxidation peak potential of methanol is about 0.60V. Compared with literature values [24–33], the electro-catalytic oxidation peak potential of methanol negative shifted more than 200mV. The result shows that the Gr-CNTs nanocomposite could improve the catalytic ability of precious metals more than what Gr or CNTs could do. Recently, Ahmed Galal group have published the similar work that graphene supported-Pt-M (M=Ru or Pd) for electrocatalytic methanol oxidation. But, in their work, the peak current of methanol oxidation is about 1.0V in 0.1M H2SO4 [33]. This study implies that the prepared catalyst has great potential for applications in various types of cells and biosensors in physiological medium. Meanwhile, the kinetic characteristics of electrocatalytic oxidation of the reaction were investigated in this work. These kinetic characteristics parameters can provide theoretical basis for further study about the oxidation mechanism of methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Multi-wall carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were obtained from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co., Ltd. The other reagent was obtained from Shanghai Chemical Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All chemicals used in this experiment were of analytical grade without further purification. All chemical solutions were prepared with deionized water purified via Milli-Q unit. Chemical solution was bubbled with high pure N2 gas for 15min to remove oxygen before the electrochemical measurement. 2.2 Substrates, instrumentation, and electrochemical setup The surface morphology of Gr-CNTs was investigated via transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30, FEI, USA) and the FTIR spectra of Gr-CNTs were recorded with a 4cm−1 spectral resolution on Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector by signal averaging 64 scans. Pt/Gr-CNTs were investigated via scanning electron microscopy (SEM, J4800, Japan) and the phase structures of the samples were measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments on an X-ray diffraction analyzer (XRD, Rigaku D/max-2400, Cu Kα radiation, λ =0.15418nm). The electrochemical experiments were carried out in an electrochemical cell with a three-electrode configuration with a CHI660C electrochemical workstation (CHI, USA). Pt/Gr-CNTs supported on glassy carbon (GC) electrode were as a working electrode. The Pt wire and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) served as a counter electrode and reference electrode. Prior to the experiment, GC electrode was mechanically polished to mirror finish by polishing with 0.05μm alumina paste, and cleaned thoroughly in an ultrasonic cleaner with deionizer water. 2.3 Preparation of graphene oxide-carbon nanotubes (GO-CNTs) nanocomposite The CNTs were purified by refluxing CNTs with 60% HNO3 at 60°C for 6h to remove the metal particles and other impurities. After the purification process, the surface oxidation of the CNTs was carried out by refluxing CNTs in 1:1 conc. H2SO4 and conc. HNO3 at 60°C for 24h. The graphite oxide was synthesized from natural graphite by a modified Hummers method [34,35], and aqueous dispersion of GO nanosheets was then used for sequential self-assembly with acid-oxidized carbon nanotubes (CNTs), forming hybrid carbon nanocomposite [36]. In brief, the proportion of CNTs to GO sheets was 1:1, the aqueous colloidal suspensions of GO nanosheets were then poured into the CNTs conglomerations, and the mixture was then sonicated for 2h. This suspension was centrifuged for 15min at 3000rpm to remove the unstabilized CNTs, thus giving a suspension of the GO-CNTs nanocomposite and the excess GO sheets in the supernatant. Next, the GO-CNTs nanocomposite were separated from the excess GO sheets by repeating centrifugation (10,000rpm, 20min) and water washing steps. The whole preparation strategy for constructing the GO-CNTs is shown in Scheme 1 . 2.4 Preparation of Pt/Gr, Pt/CNTs, Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite About deposition of Pt, there are several reports in the literature [37,38,24]. In this work, the formation of Pt nanoparticles on the Gr-CNTs was carried out by a chemical coreduction of Pt precursor salts in ethylene glycol (EG)–water solutions in our previous work [39]. In brief, 100mg GO-CNTs was added into 100mL aqueous solution containing 0.02mM H2PtCl6, and then the mixture was ultrasonically treated for 1.5h to form a stable GO-CNTs colloid. Sequentially, 40mL of EG was injected into the mixture with magnetic stirring for 1h and then the mixture was kept at 130°C for 12h under magnetic stirring. The final Pt/Gr-CNTs composites were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, dried in a vacuum desiccator. The Pt/Gr and Pt/CNTs catalysts were prepared under the same procedures. 2.5 Fabrication of the modified electrode Prior to be modified, the bare GCE was first polished with abrasive paper and then with alumina slurry on microcloth pads, followed by rinsing with water and ethanol and briefly cleaning in an ultrasonic bath, then rinsed thoroughly in deionized water and dried in air. Typically, 8.5μL of Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite was spread on the surface of the cleaned GCE with a microinjector. In a similar way, Pt/Gr/GCE and Pt/CNTs/GCE were obtained by casting 8.5μL Pt/Gr and Pt/CNTs nanocomposite on the GCE surface respectively. When not in use, the sensor was preserved at room temperature. The Pt-loading of these nanocomposites was measured by ICP (SPS7700, Seiko Instruments). The Pt/CNTs, Pt/Gr and Pt/Gr-CNTs were dissolved in dilute aqua Fortis for detection by ICP with a resolution of 0.01μg/mg. The Pt-loading of Pt/Gr-CNTs is 0.067mg/cm2 (RSD=1.8%, N =6) (note: the area is the surface of glass carbon electrode). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 FTIR spectra analysis and surface morphology of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectra of pristine CNTs, Gr sheets, and Gr-CNTs nanocomposite mainly exhibit the characteristic peaks of hydrophilic oxygen groups. It is well known that carboxylic acid groups of graphene are unlikely to be reduced by EG under the given reaction conditions [40]. These groups should therefore remain in the reduced product as confirmed by FTIR analysis. In the FTIR spectra of the graphene and CNTs powders, the broad absorption band at about 3425cm−1 is related to O–H stretching vibrations, and the absorption peak at about 1560 and 1637cm−1 from the carbonyl and carboxyl groups are present. The abundant presence of these oxygen-containing functional groups on the edge of Gr sheets and CNTs, allows graphene and Gr-CNTs composite to readily disperse in water [41]. Fig. 2 shows the TEM micrographs of the Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. It was shown that the layered structure of graphene nanosheets and the Gr-CNTs nanocomposite has the intrinsic feature of both CNTs and graphene: CNTs and Gr were corrugated and scrolled together. The inset in Fig. 2 depicts the digital pictures of CNTs suspension liquid, GO-CNTs and Gr-CNTs hydrosol, respectively. In this work, we found that the black dispersion of GO-CNTs and Gr-CNTs nanocomposites is very stable at room temperature without any precipitation upon storage for several weeks. It is reasonable to suppose that there are hydrophilic oxygen groups at the edge of graphene nanosheets which consist of multiple aromatic regions. These hydrophilic oxygen groups can enhance the stability of Gr in water. The π-conjugated multiple aromatic regions of Gr sheets could interact with the sidewalls of CNTs through the π-stacking interaction, while the hydrophilic oxygen groups can maintain the water solubility of the Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. And the CNTs can prevent the agglomeration of Gr in effect to keep the excellent monolayer structure of Gr. Thereby, it can exert the function of Gr nanosheets, such as high electrical conductivity and high specific surface area. The Gr-CNTs nanocomposite shows potential applications in functional nanocomposite and biosensors. And the Gr-CNTs were demonstrated to possess an interconnected network of carbon structures with well-defined nanopores which was promising for super capacitor electrodes for its high efficiency of catalytic activity and cheapness. The preparation of Gr-CNTs also will give us a new way for the Gr applications in colloidal chemistry and biosensors. 3.2 Surface morphology and phase structures of Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite The surface morphology of the Gr-CNTs nanosheets and Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite was investigated via SEM. Fig. 3(a) is the SEM of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite and (b) is the Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. It can be clearly seen that the CNTs and the layered structure of Gr nanosheets, and the Pt nanoparticles are deposited on the surface of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. The SEM image of Pt/Gr-CNTs clearly illustrates that highly dispersed nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on Gr-CNTs. Fig. 4(a) shows the XRD patterns of graphene nanosheets. There is a characteristic diffraction peak at ca. 24.034° of Gr, corresponding to the graphitic (002) and (100) face [42–46]. The interlayer spacing between the Gr sheets is 0.7508nm. We have fitted the (002) profiles to obtain the number of layers of the graphene samples. By analyzing this peak through the Lorentzian fitting and Scherrer equation [42], the average number of Gr primarily consists of ∼80 layers which are in conformity with the literature [42]. Fig. 4(b) shows X-ray diffractions of Pt/Gr-CNTs. The strong diffraction peaks at 2θ =39.8°, 46.0°, 68.1° and 81.2° can be assigned to the characteristic (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystalline planes of Pt [39,23], respectively, which possesses face-centered-cubic (fcc) structure. According to the results obtained from TEM, SEM and XRD, it can be concluded that Pt nanoparticles were successfully deposited on the surface of the Gr-CNTs composite. 3.3 Effects of optimization of the amount of Pt/Gr-CNTs composite The effect of 1mg/mL Pt/Gr-CNTs loading ranging from 2.0 to 13.5μL, on the cyclic voltammetry of 0.25M CH3OH in 0.5M Na2SO4 was studied. The current response increased with increasing volume of Pt/Gr-CNTs from 2.0 to 8.5μL. The further increase caused a gradual decrease in the peak current of CH3OH, which could possibly be related to the increased film thickness. As a result, 8.5μL of 1mg/mL Pt/Gr-CNTs suspension was selected as the optimum volume for the preparation of the modified electrode. 3.4 Electrocatalytic activity for Pt/Gr-CNTs modified electrode The electrocatalytic behavior of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs was studied in different medium, such as HClO4, H2SO4, NaClO4, KNO3 and Na2SO4, HAc–NaAc buffer and Na2HPO4–NaH2PO4 buffer. It was found that the oxide peak current of methanol is high in Na2SO4 than in other medium. Electrochemical behavior of the modified electrode was investigated using [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− as a redox probe by cyclic voltammetry. Fig. 5 shows the cyclic voltammograms of Pt/CNTs (curve a), Pt/Gr (curve b) and Pt/Gr-CNTs (curve c) obtained in 5.0mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− (1:1) solution containing 0.1M KCl. When the electrode was coated with Pt/Gr-CNTs, an increase in peak currents (Ip) was observed. It indicated that the sandwich structure of Pt/Gr-CNTs could increase the electron transfer rate between electrode surface and [Fe(CN)6]3−/4−. Compared with Pt/CNTs and Pt/Gr, the peak currents of Pt/Gr-CNTs increased dramatically. The results indicated that Pt/Gr-CNTs modified glass carbon electrode could greatly increase the electron transfer rate of [Fe(CN)6]3−/4−. This electrocatalytic activity toward [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− could be due to the unique electronic properties of Pt/Gr-CNTs which accelerates electron transfer rate via improved conductivity and the high specific surface area of Gr-CNTs. It was attribute to the CNTs can be best for electron transfer and expand the layer distance between Gr sheets. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is also an efficient tool for studying the interface properties of surface-modified electrodes. The charge-transfer resistance (R ct) at the electrode surface is equal to the semicircle diameter of EIS and can be used to describe the interface properties of the electrode. Thus, the capability of electron transfer of different electrodes was further investigated by EIS experiments. Fig. 6 indicates the results for the impedance spectrum on Pt/CNTs (curve a), Pt/Gr (curve b) and Pt/Gr-CNTs (curve c) in a solution of 5mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− in 0.1M KCl. The Randles circuit was chosen to fit the impedance data obtained (inset of Fig. 6). It is found that Pt/Gr-CNTs have a lower charge-transfer resistance value than that of Pt/Gr and Pt/CNTs, demonstrating that Pt/Gr-CNTs have higher electrochemical activity than Pt/Gr and Pt/CNTs. Stable steady-state responses of the different modified electrode are shown in Fig. 7 . The chronoamperometric technique is an effective method to evaluate the electrocatalytic activity and stability of catalysts. The potential of the electrode was held at 0.60V and the current flowing through the electrode was monitored for a period of 400s. The high current observed in the initial stage originates from the double layer charging. The initial current of curves b and c attenuated sharply and attained the steady state. The stable current on the Pt/Gr-CNTs electrode is about 6 times higher than that of Pt/Gr electrode and about 10 times higher than Pt/CNTs electrode. It shows that the Gr-CNTs were excellent supporter of catalysis. The highly electrocatalytic activity and stability of Pt/Gr-CNTs electrode due to the sandwich lamination structure of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite may increase specific surface area of the electrode. The synergistic reaction of Gr-CNTs with noble metal is the principal factor to increase the catalysis ability of Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite in neutrality medium or in acid medium. Fig. 8 compares the electrocatalytic activity of Pt nanoparticles supported on Gr-CNTs, Gr, and CNTs nanocomposite toward the methanol oxidation in a 0.5M Na2SO4 +0.25M CH3OH solution (curve a is Pt/Gr-CNTs, curve b is Pt/Gr, curve c Pt/CNTs, curve d is Gr-CNTs), and curve e is Pt/Gr-CNTs in the absence of methanol in Na2SO4 solution. It could be clearly seen that the electrocatalytic oxidation current curve of methanol on different electrode was identical: the oxidation peak appearing in the process of the forward scan was due to the process of methanol oxidation [47] and this anodic peak in the reverse scan could be attributed to the removal of the incompletely oxidized carbonaceous species formed in the forward scan [48]. The magnitude of the peak current in the forward scan corresponds to the catalytic activity of the Pt-based catalysts for the methanol oxidation reaction. The peak potential of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs was about 0.60V. Compared with methanol oxidation in H2SO4 solution [24–32], the peak potential of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs moved to more negative value (about 200mV). It showed that methanol oxidation is much easier on Pt/Gr-CNTs than reported in literature. It was attribute to the presence of CNTs in Gr-CNTs maintained the monolayer structural of Gr which effectively improve the electrocatalytic activity of Pt/Gr-CNTs. The oxidation peak current of methanol on Pt/Gr-CNTs (curve a) was the highest between these electro catalysts: Pt/Gr (curve b) and Pt/CNTs (curve c). 3.5 Evaluation the electrochemical kinetic parameters of methanol oxidation at Pt/Gr-CNTs catalysts The pH value of the solution has great effect on the behavior of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs catalysts. In order to obtain further experiment data for the methanol electrocatalytic oxidation, the voltammetry response to varying pH range from 1.0 to 12.0 was examined as shown in Fig. 9 (the composition of the solutions is Na2SO4 and different content of H2SO4 or NaOH with the different values of pH), and the relationship of I pa and pH is shown in the inset of Fig. 9. pH from 1.0 to 7.0, the oxidation peak current of methanol increases with pH (curves a–d), after pH>7.0, the oxidation peak current decreased gradually with pH increasing (curves e and f). The potential of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs has a relationship with the pH value. A good linear regression equation as E pa (V)=0.569−0.011 pH (n =9, r =0.994) was obtained between the potential value and pH. The results show that pH 7.0 is an optimum condition for electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol. Because of the shifted potential and electro catalysis peak current values for electro-oxidation of methanol are maximum at this pH. The results of a series of CV experiments at various scan rates (namely 10, 30, 40, 50, 60, 80, and 100mV/s) carried out on the Pt/Gr-CNTs modified electrode are shown in Fig. 10(a). It can be clearly seen that the peak current of methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs increases with scan rate increasing in 0.25M CH3OH+0.5M Na2SO4 under deoxygenated conditions. As shown in Fig. 10(b), the peak current increased linearly with the scan rate (ν 1/2) in the range of 10–100mV/s: I pa (μA)=187.63+28.46ν 1/2 (mV/s) (r =0.9984). It indicates that the oxidation of methanol on Pt/Gr-CNTs/GCE is a diffusion-controlled process. In order to get the information on the dynamic parameter of this process, cyclic voltammograms of the methanol oxidation on Pt/Gr-CNTs with different scanning rate a Tafel plot was drawn using the data derived from the current–voltage curve at scanning rate from 10 to 100mV/s. In fact, plot of E pa (mV) vs. log ν (mV/s) gives a straight line, the linear regression equation: E pa (mV)=47.12 logν (mV/s)+443.3 (r =0.9939), the line in the inset of Fig. 10 shows that oxidation peak potentials E pa are proportional to log ν. The slope of E pa vs. log ν is ∂E pa/∂(logν)=47.12mV. The Tafel slope may be estimated according to the equation for a totally irreversible diffusion-controlled process [49]. (1) E pa = b log ν 2 + const. On the basis of the equation, the slope of E pa vs. log ν is b/2, where b indicates the Tafel slope (the line in the iconography of Fig. 10). So b =2×∂E pa/∂(log ν)=94.24mV. From the equation: (2) b = 2.3 R T n α F While assuming n =4 [50], the charge transfer coefficient α =0.84. In our experiment the electrode area and the apparent diffusion coefficients for methanol in different medium were determined using chronocoulometry (CC) [51]: (3) Q = 2 n F A c D t π + Q d l + Q a d s where Q is the total charge; n, the number of electrons transfer involved in the electrochemical oxidation; A, the electrode area (cm2); c, the electroactive species concentration (M); D, the diffusion coefficient (cm2/s) and t, time (ms). Plots of Q vs. t 1/2 give a good straight line, from the slopes of the plots of Q vs. t 1/2, [Fe(CN)6]3− (in 1mol/L KCl as supporting electrolyte, the diffusivity coefficient of [Fe(CN)6]3− is 7.6×10−6 cm2/s) was using as a model, work out the electrode area of Pt/Gr-CNTs can be calculated and the value is 0.1649cm2 and the value of the diffusion coefficients (D) of methanol is (2.706±0.05)×10−6 cm2/s. The electrode reaction apparent rate constant k f can be obtained from the following equation [51]: (4) I ( t ) = n F A K f c 1 − 2 H t π In which, (5) H ≡ K f D OX 1 / 2 + K b D Rd 1 / 2 For the totally irreversible electrochemical reaction, k b =0. The k f is determined by chronoamperometry (CA). When t approaches 0, the plot of I(t) vs. t 1/2 gives a good straight line. Therefore, k f can be calculated from the slope and intercept of CA curves is (3.56±0.05)×10−4 cms−1. Fig. 11 shows the effects of the methanol concentration on the Pt/Gr-CNTs electrodes. It is noticeable that the oxidation peak current increased when the methanol concentration was increased from 0.04 to 1.00M. The peak current is proportional to the concentration of methanol in the range of 0.04 to 1.00M with the linear regression equation: I pa (mA)=0.2736+0.1672 c (mol/L) (r =0.996). This also indicates that the catalytic process is controlled by diffusion in the concentration range from 0.04 to 1.00M. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have demonstrated that the sandwich lamination structure of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite synthesized by a facile method. The characteristics of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite, such as simple processing and high specific surface area are attractive for the development of high efficiency integrated electrochemical sensors. The Gr-CNTs nanostructure can improve the electrocatalytic performance of Pt nanoparticles in neutral medium. Particularly, as fundus material, Gr-CNTs nanocomposite is very useful and is supposed to be applied in various types of cells in acid medium and biosensors in physiological medium. At the same time, we obtained kinetic characteristics parameters of electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol in neutral medium. These kinetic characteristics parameters can provide theoretical basis for further study of the oxidation mechanism of methanol. coredata.dc:description: The sandwich lamination structure of graphene-multi-walled carbon nanotubes (Gr-CNTs) nanocomposite has been fabricated through in situ facile and green method. Then Pt nanoparticles are fabricated on Gr-CNTs via a simple one-step chemical reduction method in ethylene glycol (EG) and water system. The Gr-CNTs nanocomposite increased the solubility of carbon nanotubes in water, and CNTs could effectively prevent the irreversible aggregation of graphene. The Pt/Gr-CNTs were further characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), which indicated that the as-synthesized Pt nanoparticles were successfully dispersed on the surface of Gr-CNTs nanocomposite. Electrochemical study has proved that the Pt/Gr-CNTs nanocomposite has higher catalytic activity in neutral medium for methanol oxidation, which is hopefully used in various types of cells and biosensors in physiological medium.
coredata.dc:title: Concise route to prepared graphene-CNTs nanocomposite supported Pt nanoparticles and used as new electrode material for electrochemical sensing
